answers.answer: Hi Cara,Are you a diabetic or just hypoglycemic? My comments would depend on which condition you have been diagnosed with. If you are diabetic this is serious. If your BS fall to 35 it can be life threatening.If you have hyprglycemia than the key is to always eat something. Your PCP should help you regulate this. I don't know if I would be comfortable with waiting three weeks. Do you live alone? Is someone generally close that can check on you?I would not purchase "glucose pills" unless your PCP agrees with it. You could call your PCP's nurse and request more direction as well as asl about the "glucose pills.":Best of luck to you. I hope you will let us know how you are doing.Take Care,Tuck

Please don't let me scare you. I apologize if I have. Apparently you are not a diabetic and this is hypoglycemia. Ppl with hypoglycemia (which is low blood sugar but not diabetes) can "faint" when their glucose becomes too low. One of my parents and a good friend have hypoglycemia. They just needs to eat frequently. Both can feel when their glucose level drops. They become lightheaded, sometimes nauseated and dizzy. Neither have had any major problems associated with the hypoglycemia.Diabetes on the other hand can be extremely dangerous if you are taking insulin and your glucose levels drop to 40. That may have been the concern you picked up in my post.I hope I have clarified myself a bit better and again I apologize if I alarmed you. It was not my intention.Best of luck and take care.Tuck

It is clear you require an evaluation for diabetes and need to be under the supervision of a nurse specializing in such matters or a physician or PA. If blood sugar is low, orange juice, a simple sugar, is the easiest way to bring it up. Clearly there seems to be something wrong in the way your system is handling glucose. I would not worry too much, but you require a professional in-person evaluation from an M.D.

I have hypoglycemia, and the way they found out was by doing the 6 hours glucose tolerance test. It is not fun, but very accurate. I would ask your doctor about having it done, it takes all day, but, you are in the lab and if anything should go wrong, you will be taken care of. Also, since they got that low of a reading, they should have drawn it again, that just does not sound right to me. I would see a good endocrinologist, they specialize in problems like this.Good luckSusie

question: Hi i was feeling so dizzy it became impossible to leave the house. I was eating frequently in fact I'm always hungry. I eat lots of sugary foods and drink a ton of gatorade which I know is high in sugar. The doctor couldn't figure it out my Blood sugar was 77 in office on the meter. But when she sent my bloodwork out it was 35. She says this is what caused my extreme dizziness. I'm supposed to follow up in 3 weeks. But i can't deal with this for that long should I get glucose pills? She told me to eat fruit but I've tried that and ... stilll dizzy. How should I handle this?
title: MY BLOOD SUGAR IS 35 AND IM DIZZY ALL DAY
